John Dryden (1631–1700) was an English poet who, like Byron, wrote satiric epics, notably |||italics|||Absalom and Achiophel|||/italics||| in 1681 and |||italics|||The Hind and Panther|||/italics||| in 1687. Byron may have liked the poetry, but it is odd that he did not take notice of the fact that, unlike Milton (see note 31), Dryden was an apostate. He turned from his Puritan background to Catholicism.

Alexander Pope (1688–1744) was an English poet, undersized and deformed (but with giant wit and intelligence), who wrote mock-heroic epics such as |||italics|||The Rape of the Lock |||/italics|||in 1712. He wrote almost entirely in couplets and was, of all English poets, the only one who may have been Byron’s superior in the savagery of his wit. Byron admired Pope more than any other poet and Byron’s first satire |||italics|||English Bards and Scotch Reviewers|||/italics||| (1809) was a deliberate, and effective, piece of writing in the style of Pope. (Other poets mentioned in this stanza were dealt with in the Dedication.)

William Sotheby was a minor literary figure whom Byron disliked. He believed Sotheby to have been the author of an anonymous and unfavorable review condemning Byron’s |||italics|||Prisoner of Chillon|||/italics|||. The surest way to worm one’s self into Byron’s disfavor was to criticize his poetry (something in which Byron closely resembles all other literary figures I have ever heard of).
The “Blues” (short for “bluestockings”; see note 297) are the learned ladies whom Byron abhors. The one referred to in the next line is very likely Lady Byron.

The |||italics|||Aeneid|||/italics||| and |||italics|||Paradise Lost|||/italics||| had twelve books (or cantos) each, while the |||italics|||Iliad|||/italics||| and |||italics|||Odyssey|||/italics||| had twenty-four apiece. Thus, either twelve or twenty-four seemed natural in an epic. Here, Byron is thinking of twelve, with the twelfth and last reserved for the climactic scene in Hell. (Byron surveying Hell, à la Dante, and inventing clever tortures for all the people in past history whom he disliked would have made fascinating reading — but, never mind, it was never to be.)

The |||italics|||British Review|||/italics||| was, of course, not really bribed; this was just Byron’s idea of a joke. (His sense of fun sometimes overstepped the bounds of what most people would consider good taste.) The shocked and humorless editor of the periodical protested his innocence vigorously, but no doubt that just added to the fun.

In 1802 the |||italics|||Edinburgh Review|||/italics||| was founded and issued in a buff-and-blue cover indicating its sympathies with the Whig Party. Its reviewers pulled no punches and when they disliked something, often enjoyed showing their own brilliance at the expense of the one they were pillorying (an occupational disease of critics which coses them uncounted friends). In 1807, when Byron was only nineteen, he published his first volume of poetry, |||italics|||Hours of Idleness|||/italics|||, and this was instantly seized upon by the |||italics|||Edinburgh Review,|||/italics||| which treated its author “very martyrly” indeed.
The review, published anonymously in the January 1808 issue, was by Henry Peter Brougham (see note 942), one of the founders of the journal, and Byron never forgave him once he discovered the identity of the author. In 1809 Byron got his (at first anonymous) revenge against the journal by publishing his brilliant satire |||italics|||English Bards and Scotch Reviewers.|||/italics|||

In 1809 dissatisfaction with the |||italics|||Edinburgh Review|||/italics||| led to the founding of a competing periodical, with Tory sympathies, in London. This |||italics|||Quarterly Review|||/italics||| was begun by John Murray, Byron’s publisher, at the urging of Sir Walter Scott. It was just as apt to overkill its targets as the |||italics|||Edinburgh Review|||/italics||| was.

This passage from Horace means “I would not have borne this in my flaming youth while Plancus was consul.” Plancus was Lucius Munatius Plancus, who was consul in 42 B.C. when Horace was twenty-three years old. Byron indicates that this means that he himself would have been a lot readier to resent a hostile review six or seven years earlier when he was twenty-three. And so he was (see note 215), but the implication that he had attained to the coolness of age now that he was thirty was an exaggerated one — his resentment of adverse criticism and his habit of returning the blow with all his might never cooled.

The Brenta River in northeastern Italy flows into the Adriatic Sea about twenty miles south of Venice. Byron was an inveterate, and brilliant, letter writer, and these letters he was now “dating” from his exile at a summer villa, seven miles inland on the left bank of Brenta.

Byron’s “flaming youth” of twenty-three (by Horatian standards) was in 1811, when George III was still king. It was in that year that George’s madness became so unmistakable that he was declared unfit to rule and the actual power turned over to his son as Regent. Of course, the old madman was still alive when Byron wrote these line and was to live (and theoretically be king) for some two more years.
Alas, Byron was never to know. He died before he was thirty-seven.

Roger Bacon (1214–1294) was an English scholar who was ahead of his time. He believed in experimentation, could make gunpowder and spectacles, dabbled in alchemy, and was greatly feared as a wizard. Tales were told of him in the aftertime that grew better in the telling. One of these is found in |||italics|||Friar Bacon and Friar Bungay|||/italics|||, the chief work of the English dramatist Robert Greene (1560–1592).
This take deals with a brazen head that Bacon had devised, one that could speak and, presumably, tell hidden things. Bacon watched for the head to speak, but sleep overcame him. While he slept, the head spoke. It said “Time is,” then half an hour later, “Time was,” and then, after yet another half hour, said “Time is past” and shattered. Only then, too late, did Bacon awake.
The tale symbolizes the fleeting of time and the lost opportunities that plague all men. Byron uses it to sigh over his lost youth (“chymic” means “alchemic” here with a back-reference to Bacon), so much of it gone in dissipation and folly, and seems to have a presentiment of his early death.

The ancient Egyptian pyramids were built in order to preserve the ruler’s mummy and the artifacts buried with it so that all (and the nation it represented) might exist in afterlife. To foil grave robbers, the pyramids were made ever larger and more complex. The largest and most complex of all was built under Cheops (or, more correctly, Khufu) who reigned about 2600 B.C. While his pyramid was the greatest, however, it was |||italics|||not|||/italics||| the first. The first was built by Zoser, half a century earlier.

True! The pyramids proved useless. All the mummies buried in them, together with other valuables, were eventually stolen, even from the Great Pyramid itself, which has stood empty for thousands of years.
The evanescence of life is stressed in the Bible, in which is written, “All flesh is grass, and all the goodliness thereof is as the flower of the field” (Isaiah 40:6).
So they are, and are taken from Southey’s |||italics|||Epilogue to the Lay of the Laureate.|||/italics||| The very title would be enough to rouse Byron’s ire.

Sancho Panca (Panza) was Don Quixote’s squire in Miguel de Cervantes’ (1547–1616) |||italics|||Don Quixote de la Mancha,|||/italics||| and is certainly the best-known squire in the world of fiction (and perhaps of fact, too).

The speculations as to the land that was now visible range over the islands of the middle and eastern Mediterranean. Mount Etna is the highest peak in Sicily, which is the largest island in the Mediterranean. Etna is an active volcano, the highest in Europe, and is located about five hundred miles southeast of Leghorn, the ship’s original destination.
Phoebus, from a Greek word meaning “brilliant,” was a natural epithet for the sun. Since, to the Greek poets, the god Apollo was identified with the sun, he was often called Phoebus Apollo.
John Tilloston (1630–1694) was an Anglican priest who also argued on the conservative side and who also published books of sermons.

Ceres was the Roman goddess, analogous to the Greek Demeter. She was the goddess of agriculture and, particularly, of grain. Our word “cereal” is derived from her name. The Roman dramatist Terence (185–159 B.C.) felt that making love (Venus) on an empty stomach (without Ceres and Bacchus) was impractical and has a character say so in his play |||italics|||The Eunuch.|||/italics||| Byron agrees, and few people as articulate as he have been so experienced; so presumably he knew.
The Stygian river, i. e., the Styx, separated the world of the living from Hades, in the Greek myths.

Gaius Julius Caesar (100–44 B.C.), who conquered Gaul, led, in his younger days, the gay life of an aristocratic wastrel. Many legends concerning his dissipation were made use of by his political enemies. Best known to the general public is the matter of his stay in Egypt in 48 B.C. There he met the young Cleopatra and had a son by her.

Sappho (see note 127) was a bluestocking in the sense that she was an educated woman. The phrase arose because in Venice in 1400 and in Paris in 1590 societies of educated women were founded, at whose soirees bluestockings were a kind of badge or uniform. The habit was taken up in England in 1780. Byron, who detested bluestockings, sometimes refers to them as “the Blues” (see note 212).

A biblical reminder of death in the midst of gaiety took place at the feast given by Belshazzar, King of Babylon (Daniel 5:1–31). A hand appeared in the midst of the feast, writing mysterious words on the wall. Only Daniel, the Jewish captive, could read and interpret the words which, he said, announced the forthcoming fall of the kingdom. And that night it fell (the Bible says).

Psyche was the pure and beautiful heroine of a legend that appeared in |||italics|||The Golden Ass|||/italics||| by Lucius Apuleius (c. 150). She was beloved by Cupid who visited her every night but only on condition that she never try to find out who he was. Once she tried to look at him, sleeping, but wax dropped from her candle and woke him. He left her and she was reunited to him only after the many long trials and dangers imposed on her by the enmity of Cupid’s mother, Venus. There was a happy ending, though, and Psyche became immortal.
To easterners, a Frank was a West European generally — the name having arisen in the times of the Crusades.

The “Islands of the Blest” was the ancient Greek version of the Paradise, a region where the heroes lived in endless bliss after death. Homer referred to it as “the Elysian Plain” (from which we call it, sometimes, “Elysium”) and located it somewhere in the west, for in his time the western Mediterranean was shrouded in mystery and was therefore a suitable place for wonders. It was the later poet Hesiod, who, in the eighth century B.C., referred to the Elysian Plain as the “Islands of the Blest.” By his time, Greek ships were exploring the coasts of the western Mediterranean and Hesiod was forced to place the Islands beyond the westernmost edge of the sea and out into Atlantic Ocean itself. (Perhaps there were dim reports of the Canary Islands, about a thousand miles southwest of the Strait of Gibraltar.)

Salamis is a small island (thirty-six square miles) just off the western shore of Attica and about ten miles west of Athens itself. After the humiliation of the battle of Marathon, the Persian empire prepared itself for a much larger effort. In 480 B.C. a large army, much larger than the force that had landed at Marathon, crossed the Hellespont into northern Greece and drove southward. Athens had to be abandoned and its citizens manned the fleet that prepared to fight the Persians while the women and children were taken to Salamis under the shadow of that fleet.
Xerxes, the Persian king (see note 168), was with his forces. He sat on an Attica height to overlook the sea fight at which he confidently expected his navy to crush the Greeks. What he saw instead was a decisive Greek sea victory that destroyed his fleet and forced him to return to Persia.

On the Persian march southward in 480, the march which ended at Salamis, they came to a narrow pass called Thermopylae, protected by a much smaller force of Greeks, led by the Spartan king, Leonidas. In the narrow pass, the Persian numbers could not be used effectively, and the Greeks held out for days. Finally, through the treason of a Greek, the Persians discovered a rocky path that could outflank the pass. The greeks were forced to retreat, but retreat was against the Spartan code, and among those who stayed were Leonidas and his contingent of 300 Spartans. These refused to surrender and fought to the end, dying to the last man, and in their death creating so heroic a legend that the effect on Greek morale was greater than any ordinary victory would have been.

The Franks, as we have noted (see note 353), were the West Europeans, and Byron sneers at their willingness to help. And yet in this case he was wrong. Byron did not live to see it, but on October 20, 1827, the decisive battle of the Greek War of Independence was fought. It was the naval battle of Navarino, fought on the western coast of the Peloponnesus. In that battle, the Turkish-Egyptian fleet was virtually annihilated by the combined ships of the British, French, and Russian navies. After that, Greek independence was assured.

John Churchill, first Duke of Marlborough (1650–1722) was a great English general who never really lost a battle and who defeated the armies of King Louis XIV of France during the War of the Spanish Succession. His victory at Blenheim in 1704 was the most notable British military feat during the four-century span between Agincourt (1415) and Waterloo (1815).

Lodovico Ariosto (1474–1533) was an Italian poet whose best-known work was the epic poem |||italics|||Orlando Furioso,|||/italics||| written in the style of the medieval knightly legends. It was a poem in, ultimately, forty-six cantos and took the poet the final thirty years of his life to write. In 1817 Byron visited Ariosto’s tomb in Ferrara.

Thetis was the mother of Achilles in Greek mythology. When Achilles was born (her only child), she foresaw that he was destined to have a short life. Attempting to avert this she dipped him in the waters of the Styx (see note 290). This gave his skin invulnerability to all weapons. Unfortunately, she held him by the heel and forgot that the water did not cover the part she held. Achilles’ heel remained vulnerable (hence the meaning of the phrase) and he was eventually killed by an arrow there. Byron feels, ruefully, that forgetfulness is a better guard against the woes of the world than physical invulnerability.

Pulci’s epic, like Ariosto’s (see note 406), dealt with Orlando, the greatest hero of the medieval hero tales. He is better known to English-speakers as Roland. In history, he was one of Charlemagne’s paladins who died in an ambush in the Pyrenees together with the rearguard that he led. It was a small skirmish but was turned by legend into a major battle. Instead of the Christian Basques who had ambushed and killed Orlando, the villains became Moors, and all kinds of flummery was added, including, “true knights, chaste dames, huge giant kings despotic,” and evil enchanters, too.
In 1605 Cervantes published the first part of |||italics|||Don Quixote|||/italics||| (see note 236), which was intended as a satire on this kind of medieval tale. Don Quixote was a poor madman of high ideals who took the tales of chivalry as literal truth and tried to live the life of one of the story-book knights, hence the word “quixotic,” meaning any action based on irrational idealism. |||italics|||Don Quixote|||/italics||| turned out to be the greatest satire ever written. Not only is it by general consent a complete masterpiece as a work of literature but it did what satires hardly ever do — it killed the thing it satirized. The medieval tale of chivalry did not survive |||italics|||Don Quixote.|||/italics|||

Ilion is one of the alternate names of Troy. The city was, according to legend, founded by Ilus, the son of Tros. The son and the father are the sources of the two alternate names. Though Troy is the better known name, the |||italics|||Iliad|||/italics||| receives its name from the other.
The ship carrying the wounded Juan was thus traveling northward through the Aegean, for the site of Troy is about 180 miles northeast of the Cyclades.

In ancient times, there were structures on the Trojan plain that were considered to be the tombs of various notables who had died in the great siege. One was thought to be Achilles’, the greatest of the Greek heroes in Homer’s epic. When Alexander the Great crossed the Dardanelles to begin his invasion of Persia, he first landed at the site of Troy and sacrificed at what was considered the tomb of Priam to avert the vengeance of the Trojan shades and then placed a garland at the tomb of Achilles, whom he always considered his model.

Patroclus was the best friend of Achilles and, everyone assumes, in view of later Greek customs, his homosexual lover as well, though Homer never says anything of the sort directly. The gentlest and most attractive of the Greek heroes, Patroclus was killed by Hector when he went to war in place of the sulking Achilles. It was his death that forced Achilles into war again.
A tomb near Achilles’ was thought to be that of Patroclus in ancient times. When Alexander placed his garland on Achilles’ tomb (see note 463), Hephaestion, his friend and, presumably, homosexual lover, placed a similar garland on that of Patroclus.

Ajax was, next to Achilles, the strongest of the Greek heroes. He was never so much as wounded in the |||italics|||Iliad|||/italics||| but his fate was tragic, nevertheless, and he never left Troy. After Achilles died, his armor was granted to Odysseus (Ulysses) for his cleverness rather than to Ajax for his strength. This was justly done, as it was Odysseus’ wiles that, in the end, destroyed Troy, and not the strength of anyone. Sheer disappointment, however, drove Ajax mad, and he killed himself.

Paris was the son of Priam and Hecuba of Troy. When he was born, Hecuba dreamed she had been delivered of a firebrand that would burn the city. It was therefore decided to expose the newborn infant on Mount Ida and leave him to die. He was, however, found and reared by a shepherd. He spent his youth, therefore, as a shepherd on Mount Ida, until his identity was discovered and he was restored to his true place as a Trojan prince (to end by being the firebrand that destroyed his city). He was noted for his beauty and in that, presumably, the shepherds Byron saw were unlike him.

Niccolò Machiavelli (1469–1527) was an Italian statesman and political scientist who in his book |||italics|||The Prince|||/italics||| wrote what he thought should be the guiding principles of those who wished to rule. The principles he devised according to practical, and not idealistic, notions; treachery and artifice were recommended as methods for maintaining power, not because such things were admirable but because they worked. The justification was that a stable government was a great good and well repaid a little roguery. A sternly moralistic idealist, who was unable to hold power and who delivered his nation over to the agonies of partisan quarreling and civil war, did no one any favors. As a result of all this, “Machiavellian” has come to mean “treacherous” or “dissimulating.”

Alexander Vasilievich Suvorov (1729–1800) is usually considered the greatest of all Russian generals; certainly he is the most colorful. The spelling “Suwarrow” is German, where the “w” is pronounced like the English “v”. Taken into the English literature, the German version, unchanged, comes to be rhymed with “sparrow” and that suits Byron, for it is easier to rhyme “Suwarrow” pronounced English fashion than “Suvorov” pronounced in any fashion.

Suvorov led Russian armies against the Turks from 1773 to 1774, and again from 1787 to 1792. During the latter war, he attempted to take Belgrade and to detach Serbia (the southern part of what now is Yugoslavia) from the Ottoman Empire. In 1789, however, he was repulsed from Widdin (or Vidin), a town on the right bank of the Danube in what is now at the northwest corner of Bulgaria.
“Voltaire” was the pen name of the French writer François Marie Arouet (1694–1778), the cleverest satirist of his age or, perhaps, of any.

Babylon reached the peak of its glory about seven centuries after the fabled Nimrod. In the sixth century B.C. it was under the rule of Nabukudurri-user, a name more familiar in the Hebrew version, Nebuchadrezzar, and still better in the misspelling found in the Book of Daniel, Nebuchadnezzar. The Greek translations of the Bible give the name (worse and worse) as Nebuchadonosor, and that is the version Byron uses in order to keep the rhythm of the line smooth.
Nebuchadrezzar reigned from 605 to 562 B.C and under him Babylon was the largest, wealthiest, and most powerful city on earth. One of his devices for beautifying the city was to cover tall mounds with earth, and plant them with trees and shrubs to create what came to be known as the “Hanging Gardens of Babylon.” These were listed by the later Greeks as among the Seven Wonders of the World.

The Bible tells us that Darius of Persia was forced to throw Daniel into a den of lions as punishment for having prayed to God against the king’s commandments. He was, however, saved from the beasts through divine intervention (Daniel 6:4–23).

In 323 B.C. Alexander the Great died in Babylon and in 312 B.C. Seleucus Nicator founded the Seleucid empire there. These were the last events of note in the great city. Seleucus founded Seleucia near Babylon as a new capital; and as the new city rose, the old city fell. By A.D. 100 Babylon was a rubbishy village and thereafter it disappeared altogether so that men were left to argue as to the exact site.

Mary Stuart (1542–1587) inherited the crown of Scotland when she was a week old. She went to France, as a child, married the French king’s oldest son when she was sixteen and, a year later, when the king died, she became Queen of France. One more year, however, and her sickly husband, Francis II, died, and Mary returned to Scotland. She was Catholic but the Scottish nobility was to a large extent Protestant and she had increasing troubles with them.
Mary was renowned for her beauty and her love affairs, but she was a poor politician and in 1568 had to flee to England. Because she had claims to the English throne and was the center of treasonable conspiracies, the English queen, Elizabeth I, imprisoned her for nineteen years and finally had her executed. Throughout her long imprisonment, many were devoted to her, in part for her beauty, or her reputation for beauty. Her tragic story has heightened that reputation with the years. She was forty-five when she died, but the faith in her continued beauty has never failed among the romantics of later generations who could not go back through time to look.

The Cato referred to here is Marcus Porcius Cato (95–46 B.C.), usually known as Cato the Younger, and the great-grandson of Marcus Porcius Cato (234–149 B.C.), or Cato the Elder. Cato the Younger was a stern stoic of rigid morality but narrow conservatism. He opposed Julius Caesar and died a suicide when Caesar’s victories made the conservative cause hopeless. His stoic superiority to emotion made it possible for him to release his wife, Marcia, when his friend Hortensius fell in love with her. After Hortensius died in 50 B.C., Cato took his wife back. There were not want of cynics, however, who pointed out that Marcia was left a rich legatee when the wealthy Hortensius died and that Cato gave his friend a poor woman and received back a rich one. If virtue always paid in this manner, vice might go out of fashion.

St. Francis of Assisi (1181–1226) was the most ardent and saintly of all those who tried to follow the teachings of Jesus literally. He founded the Franciscans, an order of mendicant friars who took the vow of poverty. St. Francis himself embraced poverty with the ardor of a groom. He called her “My Lady Poverty” and it is to her that Byron refers here as “St. Francis’ paramour.” There was also a legend that he kept seven great balls of snow near his cell and referred to the largest as his wife. Apparently he had to embrace the snow to quell occasional sexual pressures. In the first canto Byron had mistakenly attributed this to St. Anthony (see note 151).

The Book of Common Prayer was prepared in 1549 at the time of the English Reformation by Thomas Cranmer, Archbishop of Canterbury. It contains the liturgy used by the Church of England and, of course, basic to it is the Nicene Creed with the curse on unbelievers.

Patagonia is the southernmost thousand-mile stretch of South America, narrowing to Cape Horn. The first Europeans to see it were Ferdinand Magellan and his crew in 1520. The primitive natives struck the Spanish explorers as having big feet, which, in Spanish, is |||italics|||pata|||/italics||||||italics|||g|||/italics||||||italics|||ó|||/italics||||||italics|||n|||/italics||||||italics|||,|||/italics||| hence the name. The reference here is not primarily to the geographical region, however, but, since big feet imply a big creature as well, to a land of giants.

Jonathan Swift (1667–1745) published his classic |||italics|||Gulliver’s Travels |||/italics|||in 1726. Gulliver’s first voyage took him to the island of Lilliput (babytalk for “little place,” I suspect) where everything was but one-twelfth the linear dimensions of ordinary things so that men are only six inches tall.

The tale of Pygmalion is told in Ovid’s |||italics|||Metamorphoses.|||/italics||| Pygmalion was a sculptor who produced a statue so beautiful he fell in love with it. He prayed to Venus, who brought the statue to life for him.

The earliest meaning of “meteor” is “an atmospheric phenomenon,” the word coming from a Greek term meaning “high in the air.” In modern times, the term has been applied to one particular high-in-the-air phenomenon, the shooting star — a piece of matter from outer space which collides with earth’s atmosphere and, in its rapid passage, is raised to bright incandescence by friction.
This is now the only meaning of the word in the popular mind and the modern meteor is not particularly associated with the North Pole. However, in Byron’s time scientists were just beginning to admit that the tales of stones that fell from heaven were, after all, true, and Byron is still using the word in its older sense. He is referring to the northern lights which are indeed bred in the neighborhood of the magnetic poles, which are near the geographical ones.

Catherine II (1729–1796) became Empress of Russia in 1762 and, with the possible exception of Peter I (1672–1725), was the land’s greatest sovereign. Both Peter and Catherine usually bear the epithet of “the Great.” When she came to the throne, the Black Sea’s shores were entirely Turkish. By the end of her reign, the northern shores of that sea were Russian and have remained so since.
See note 658.

Byron proceeds to defend himself against those who denounced |||italics|||Don Juan|||/italics||| for its cynicism by pointing out the long and respected history of satire. Humanity, after all, has been denounced or ridiculed for its faults by many renowned authors, philosophers, and theologians. Dante, for instance, in |||italics|||The Divine Comedy|||/italics||| placed many human beings by name (and some of them of the highest station) in Hell.
The biblical Book of Proverbs (attributed to Solomon by tradition) denounces many human failings.
See note 440.

Jonathan Swift, the Dublin-born English writer best known for |||italics|||Gulliver’s Travels|||/italics||| (see note 639), was one of the most savagely effective satirists in history. In his |||italics|||Modest Proposal|||/italics||| he suggested that Irish poverty be relieved by having Irish parents fatten their children and sell them as food. So straight-faced was he in this proposal that there were not wanting fools who thought he was seriously advocating cannibalism. In |||italics|||Gulliver’s Travels|||/italics||| he had a giant say to Gulliver of mankind, “I cannot but conclude the bulk of your natives to be the most pernicious race of little vermin that nature ever suffered to crawl upon the surface of the earth.”
See note 475.

François de La Rochefoucauld (1613–1680) was a French writer who intrigued against both Cardinal Richelieu and Jules Mazarin (two powerful political figures under Louis XIII and Louis XIV, respectively) and yet, wonder of wonders, survived each. He is best known for his |||italics|||Maxims,|||/italics||| first published anonymously in 1665, in which he expressed his cynical views of mankind in the most compressed possible way. Thus: “We give nothing more generously than advice” and “We all have strength enough to endure the misfortunes of another.”

François de Salignac de La Mothe-Fénelon (1651–1715) was a French churchman who was an important pioneer in the theory of education. Although a saintly man, he did get in trouble with the government when, in 1699, he published the novel |||italics|||Telemachus|||/italics||| which was considered a satire directed at Louis XIV.

Martin Luther (1483–1546) was the founder of Lutheranism and wrote copiously on religious and political matters. Like most important theologians, he felt called upon, in the name of a merciful and loving God, to denounce almost all human beings as sinners and almost all human ways as sins.
Plato (427–347 B.C.) wrote |||italics|||The Republic|||/italics|||, in which he described his idea of an ideal government, and that, of course, involved the condemnation of real governments.
See note 279.
John Wesley (1703–1791) was the founder of Methodism and was another of the theologians who denounced sin.
Jean Jacques Rousseau (1712–1778) was a French writer who wrote on education and on the social basis of government. He was profoundly dissatisfied with the social structure of Europe in his time.
Cato the Younger (see note 621) was known for his absolute honesty in a day when even mild honesty was remarkable for its absence.

Diogenes (412–323 B.C.) was a Greek philosopher who is the best-known example of the philosophic school known as “Cynicism.” He believed in the most simple possible life, in abandoning all social conventions as artificial and hypocritical. His standard of absolute honesty and poverty is almost impossible to follow.

Socrates (470–399 B.C.) was an Athenian philosopher who was judged by the Delphic oracle to be the wisest of all men. When told of this, Socrates answered wryly, “If I am the wisest of all men, surely it is because I, alone of all men, know that I know nothing.”
This is not to be taken as meaning that nothing can be known — as Byron ironically takes it in the next lines. What Socrates meant was that he did not accept anything without question; that he subjected everything he |||italics|||seemed|||/italics||| to know to serious inquiry on the assumption that he might not really know what he thought he knew.

Isaac Newton (1642–1727) was the English mathematician and scientist who deduced the binomial theorem, discovered calculus, invented the reflecting telescope, founded the science of optics, and worked out the law of universal gravitation —all of this making him, by common consent and beyond argument, the greatest scientist who ever lived. He had many faults but among his virtues was an engaging modesty. He said, “I do not know what I may appear to the world; but to myself I seem to have been only like a boy playing on the sea-shore, and diverting myself in now and then finding a smoother pebble or a prettier shell than ordinary, whilst the great ocean of truth lay all undiscovered before me.”
The biblical Book of Ecclesiastes says, “Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, vanity of vanities; all is vanity” (Ecclesiastes 1:2), where “vanity” means futility.

Byron, proudly refusing to moderate the force of his satire, here deliberately misquotes a passage from the Introduction to |||italics|||The Faerie Queen|||/italics||| by Edmund Spencer (1552–1599). The passage should properly read, “Fierce wars and faithful loves shall moralize my song.” Byron had read parts of |||italics|||Faerie Queen|||/italics||| during his Mediterranean tour and had been sufficiently impressed to decide to write |||italics|||Childe Harold’s Pilgrimage|||/italics||| in Spenserian stanzas.

We are back to Suvorov (see note 539). “Souvaroff” is the French spelling and “Suwarrow” the German (|||italics|||not |||/italics|||English or “Anglice”). Byron uses both spellings in this canto and the next, according to the exigencies of rhyme and meter.

Suvorov’s love for blood is more a love of victory, and victories he gained. In the last year of his life he was even able to defeat the French armies in Italy, despite the disadvantage of having the Austrians as allies. (To be sure, the French armies were not, at this time, led by Napoleon.)
However, since Russian soldiers, through most of history, have been characterized by poor equipment, poor training, but almost superhuman courage, the one way to win victory with them was to march them forward regardless of losses. Suvorov’s victories were therefore bloody ones.

Ismail (or, more correctly, Izmail) is, as Byron says, on the left bank (that is, the northern side of an eastward flowing river) of the Danube. The city is in southern Bessarabia, a province which in the time in which this canto is set (1790) was part of the Ottoman empire. In 1812 Russia wrested the province from the Turks and in Byron’s time, province and city were Russian. (In 1856, in the aftermath of Russia’s defeat in the Crimean War, the province was transferred to the new nation of Romania. It went back to Russia in 1878, back to Romania in 1918, and to the Soviet Union in 1945.)

Izmail is some forty miles upstream from the mouth of the Danube. Since a verst (a Russian unit of distance) is about ⅔ of a mile, this distance represents sixty versts, and not quite eighty as Byron says. A toise is a French unit of distance, equal to about two yards, so that the circumference of the walls of the city is given as some three and a half miles.
Byron obtained the detail on Izmail, its siege and its storming, from a French book entitled (in English) |||italics|||Essay on the Ancient and Modern History of New Russia|||/italics||| by Marquis Gabriel de Castelnau, published in three volumes in 1820. By “New Russia” is meant central and southern Ukraine (see note 738), most of which had been Russian territory for less than half a century at the time the book was written. Byron followed the book very closely and made no secret of that. Indeed, he said as much in the Introduction that accompanied the publication of the third volume of |||italics|||Don Juan|||/italics|||.

Sébastien Le Prestre, Marquis de Vauban (1633–1707) was a master of fortification who served Louis XIV of France. It was a period when wars consisted largely of sieges, and Vauban was an extremely valuable soldier who knew how to direct a siege so as to take advantage of weaknesses in the fortifications and how to construct fortifications so as to minimize those weaknesses.

The legend of St. George arose in medieval times. It tells of a Christian martyr who lived in Palestine and who died in 303 during the last great Roman persecution of the Christians. The event in George’s life which attracted most notice was his rescue of a maiden from the wicked jaws of a dragon — which he slew. He was always portrayed as clad in armor “cap-à-pie” (from a French phrase meaning “from head to foot”) with a lance on rest, facing the dragon. The appearance and deed were knightly and to the medieval Norman rulers of England, St. George appeared to be the right kind of saint. Edward III (1312–1377) fancied himself a knight and adopted St. George as England’s patron saint; hence Byron calls him “our St. George.”

A casemate is a bomb-proof shelter, usually of masonry, within which a cannon, or anything else, can be placed to keep it from harm. A barbette is a low mound behind which the cannon can be placed and over which it can be fired. A cavalier is a mound upon which guns can be placed. Byron got these details from Castelnau, of course (see note 706).
“Allah” is the Arabic word for “God,” and “Bis Millah” is from an Arabic expression meaning “in the name of God.”

“Cossaque” is the French spelling of the word that in English is usually spelled “Cossack”. It is a distortion of the Russian word |||italics|||kazak,|||/italics||| or Turkish |||italics|||gazaq|||/italics|||, which means “adventurer” and was applied to those fugitives who fled from the cramped life within settled states to take up the free nomadic ways on the steppes north of the Black Sea which, until modern times, were under the control of no state. The Cossacks included Poles, Ukranians, Russians, Turks, and so on.
During the sixteenth century the Poles and Russians strove to bring the Cossack bands under control, for they were magnificent horsemen and hardy fighters — a danger if left to themselves, but a huge asset if absorbed. After the time of Peter the Great it was clear that the Russians would win the race, and in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries they were the mainstay of the Russian army and the chief support of the throne against internal unrest. Naturally, however, though Russian soldiers might be called Cossacks generally, this is poetic license. Most were not.
See note 463.
Byron can’t resist having fun with Russian names. Most of those that follow need not be take seriously, of course.

Moscow was not the seat of the Russian court in Byron’s time, but it had been the capital before 1703 (and was to be the capital again after 1917). Even in the two-century period when St. Petersburg was the capital, Moscow remained the true heart of Russia as far as the Russians themselves were concerned. Buried deep in the core of at least the European portion of the nation, it represented them far more than did the more-than-half-German St. Petersburg.

Londonderry is another reference to Castlereagh (see note 34). On the death of his father in 1821, Castlereagh became the second Marquis of Londonderry, but Byron pursues his poor oratory and him under his new name. Castlereagh died a suicide even while this canto was being written, but Byron had it published without removing the slur, expressing his continued hatred of the man in the somewhat defensive Introduction that accompanied this portion of |||italics|||Don Juan|||/italics|||.
A mufti is one who expounds Islamic law.

Mercenaries, fighting in foreign armies in order to hold the high rank they could not qualify for in their native forces, and in order to share in loot, are quite apt to wish to avoid too-easy identification and therefore adopt pseudonyms which are as bland as possible. In the case of Englishmen, such particularly common surnames as Thomson and Smith, with first names as common as Jack, Bill, and Jemmy (James) would be used most frequently. Naturally, some real and even important people may have such names and Byron satirically pretends that the Jemmy Thomsons called themselves so in honor of James Thomson (1700–1748), the first of the nature poets, whose best-known hold on fame is that he wrote the words to “Rule, Britannia.”
There was a Peter Smith, in a farce called |||italics|||Love Laughs at Locksmiths|||/italics||| by George Colman (1762–1836), who, while “in country quarters at Halifax,” seduced a maid.

The Mongol hordes, or Tatars (usually, but wrongly, called Tartars; see note 201) invaded Russia in 1224, and by 1240 had conquered the land. They remained in control for three centuries, and during that time the Russians were out of touch with the currents of change in the rest of Europe. Because the Russians seemed backward and uncivilized to the polished aristocrats of the West and because it was assumed there had been interbreeding, one could, and often did, flippantly refer to Russians as “Tartars.” Napoleon, on St. Helena, had said bitterly, “Scratch a Russian and you’ll find a Tartar.” Well, he should know, to his sorrow.

Shakespeare in all his plays showed a sardonic dislike of war. There is Falstaff’s dry catechism on “honor” in |||italics|||Henry IV, Part One|||/italics||| (V, I, 129–141), for instance, and Hamlet, who notes
|||comment-quote|||The imminent death of twenty thousand men
That for a fantasy and trick of fame
Go to their graves...|||/comment-quote|||
|||comment-quote-attr|||IV, iv, 60–62|||/comment-quote-attr|||

Byron satirizes the attitudes of many Englishmen who viewed the Frenchmen as their traditional and eternal foe. The English and French had been fighting since 1066, when the Normans from northern France had conquered England. The high points, for the English, were the battle of Agincourt in 1415 and the battle of Waterloo in 1815. Oddly enough (and Byron couldn’t possibly have guessed it), Waterloo was the last battle the English and the French were to fight. Since then, they have been allies in three wars, the Crimean, World War I, and World War II, and opponents in none.
John Bull, as a symbol of the Englishman, originated in 1712 with a political satire written by John Arbuthnot (1667–1735) against the Duke of Marlborough (see note 389) and entitled |||italics|||The History of John Bull|||/italics|||. John was chosen as the most common English first name and Bull as a name indicating stubborn strength. In the same satire the Frenchman is called Lewis Baboon, the French king at the time being Lewis XIV of the house of Bourbon.

Smith is indeed the most common name in English and Byron indicates, jokingly, that it might have been borne by the first man. Or is it a reference to Adam Smith (1723–1790), the great economist, whose book |||italics|||Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations,|||/italics||| published in 1776, made him the most famous Smith of his times and one of the most famous of any times?
Longman was a family of English publishers. Their firm published Wordsworth, Coleridge, and Southey.
John Murray was Byron’s long-time publisher, although this present part of |||italics|||Don Juan|||/italics||| was shifted to another.
Delhis were elite Turkish troops. The word means, literally, “madmen” because they were expected to fight with insane disregard of their own safety.
Count Damas was one of the Frenchmen in the service of Russia; Byron names some of them despite his mockingly patriotic refusal to do so nine stanzas before.
The reference is to Castelnau (see note 706).

Prince Charles Joseph von Ligne (1735–1814) was an Austrian soldier, born in what is now Belgium. In 1780 he was sent by Joseph II of Austria on a mission to Catherine II of Russia. He greatly impressed her, and in 1786, when he returned to Russia, he traveled with her on her tour of the Ukraine. She created him a field marshal of the Russian army.

Count Andrault de Langeron (1763–1831) was a Frenchman who fought with the Russians not only against the Turks, but also against the French during the Napoleonic Wars. He fought at the battle of Austerlitz in 1805 and at the battle of Leipzig in 1813.
French for “brave knights.”
Langeron was certainly still alive when these lines were written. In fact, he was serving Russia as governor of the Ukraine.
See note 47.
Joseph de Ribas was a Naples-born Spaniard who commanded the Russian naval flotilla attacking Izmail.

Gregory Alexandrovich Potëmkin (1739–1791) was the most famous of the lovers of Catherine II. Though he remained her love for only five years, from 1771 to 1776, he stayed on as her prime minister (so to speak) for the rest of his life. He brought attention to himself first in 1769 when he fought with reckless bravery against the Turks (hence Byron’s remark in preceding stanza that his manhood could not be called in question—to say nothing of the fact that he kept Catherine satisfied for five years—and that were he not a Hercules of strength he would have been quickly killed).
He was in charge of the military effort against the Turks at the time of the siege of Izmail, the last task of his life. In 1791 he returned to St. Petersburg, where his intrigues displeased the Empress. She sent him back to Bessarabia to conduct peace negotiations with the Turks. Forty miles short of the goal he developed a fever, and when he insisted on overeating voraciously, he suffered agonies of intestinal cramps (to which Byron refers as “indigestion”). He was placed under a tree by his distracted attendants, for they were far from any sentiment, and there he died in the “province he head wasted” with warfare.

The ancient Spartans (see note 116) cultivated the habit of speaking briefly and concisely. The district surrounding the city of Sparta was Laconia, so that to speak tersely (as Potëmkin iss about to be described as doing) is to be “laconic.”

Potëmkin’s headquarters were at Iasi (or Jassy), a town on a tributary of the Prut River and about 140 miles north of Izmail. He had been supervising the siege of the fortress for seven moths and he was growing impatient. The failure to take it was damaging his reputation. In Iasi he eased his growing moroseness by surrounding himself with soft living. In an effort to amuse him, one of the ladies at his sultanlike “court” pretended to tell his fortune in the cards and to predict that Izmail would fall in three weeks. Potëmkin, galvanized into action, said he would do better than that. He called for Suvorov, who almost always accomplished the tasks he was set (and who never counted the cost), and ordered him to take Izmail in three days.

To the Moslems, pork is forbidden as an article of diet. To “save one’s bacon” is a slang expression meaning to save one’s life. This phrase is supposed to have originated from the great care country folk used to have to take of their bacon and other supplies intended to support life through the winter from the depredations of the family dogs and other animals.
The Ukraine is so-called from the Russian word for “frontier.” It was the Russian frontier against Turks, Tatars, and Poles for centuries.
See note 283.

Byron finds grim humor in the fact that the Russian camp should rejoice in the arrival of Suvorov, when he will bring death to so many by his reckless win-at-any-price attack. However, he finds this blind joy, where no joy should be, common elsewhere, too, as (see the previous stanza) in contemporary Britain. One is reminded of the almost hysterical joy in the European capitals when World War I broke out. It was the last time of joy over war. By World War II everyone had learned better.

The will-o’-the-wisp is a faint light that appears over marshy or boggy places. It is usually thought to result from the spontaneous combustion of methane, or marsh gas, produced by decaying vegetable matter. Travelers lost at night sometimes make for these lights, thinking them to be carried by other men or to represent lamplight in houses and find themselves hopelessly mired in the marsh as a result.
Fascines are bundles of sticks used for filling in ditches, raising guns, and other makeshift purposes.

Suvorov was quite old. He was sixty-one years of age at the time of the siege of Izmail. He was also small in stature and eccentric. For instance, he insisted on leading the life of a common soldier on a campaign and sharing their privations—something even two-bit, incompetent officers in the Russian army of the time knew better than to do. (They didn’t often win victories either.) Suvorov also had a biting wit that made him many enemies, and his clownishness sometimes placed him under the suspicion of being mad.

Although commanding general, Suvorov did indeed, when necessary, do the job of a corporal. The Russian privates loved him for it and went to their death for him with that extra enthusiasm that sometimes made the difference.

A salamander in ancient legend was a lizardlike monster that was supposed to be able to live in fire. The name is now given to certain tailed amphibians that are as little able (or less) to live in fire as we are.

The reference to Jacob is derived from a biblical passage which deals with Jacob’s flight from his brother Esau. Jacob dreamed about “a ladder set up on the earth, and the top of it reached to heaven: and behold the angels of God ascending and descending on it” (Genesis 28:12). The ladders used during sieges are used for the ascent and descent of soldiers, who are certainly little enough like angels.

Mars, of course, was the god of war, Momus, the god of mockery. Suvorov, who customarily asked superhuman feats of his men, encouraged them to die for him by treating them on their own terms and in their own language, with rough humor.
Harlequin is a jesting spirit in the British pantomime.
Calmucks (or Kalmucks or Kalmyks) were a people related to the Tatars and lived on the northwestern shore of the Caspian Sea.

Apparently Don Juan, who was left at the end of the previous canto, in imminent peril from the vengeful Gulbeyaz, is now safe. What happened? Byron, with grand indifference, doesn’t bother to explain in detail. Presumably, Baba the eunuch, afraid that the Sultana will either order his own execution, along with that of Juan and Dudu, as knowing too much or that she would order his execution afterward in regret for that of Juan, arranged an escape. He, Johnson (Juan’s companion in the slave market), Don Juan, and Dudu left Constantinople hurriedly (somehow) and made their way to the frontier and the Russian army (somehow). And who was the second woman? It is never made clear.
See note 540.

For Job’s wife, see note 197. As for his friends, who came to visit him and console him, their notion of consolation was to maintain that he was suffering because he had sinned and that he therefore deserved his sorrows.
See note 461.
Priam’s son is Hector, the bravest of the Trojan fighters, and, in some ways, the real hero of the |||italics|||Iliad.|||/italics|||
See note 268.
Leonidas was the Spartan king who led the three hundred at Thermopylae (see note 372).
Julius Caesar (see note 293) wrote his |||italics|||Commentaries|||/italics||| to describe his campaigns in Gaul, and these are probably the most successful war memoirs in history.

The Babylonian harlot is described in the last book of the Bible where the narrator is told by an angel, “Come hither; I will shew unto thee the judgement of the great whore that sitteth upon many waters” (Revelation 17:1). The narrator goes on to say, “And the woman was arrayed in purple and scarlet colour, and decked with gold and precious stones and pearls.... And upon her forehead was a name written, MYSTERY, BABYLON THE GREAT, THE MOTHER OF HARLOTS...” (Revelation 17:4,5).

A “bob” is the name given to certain changes rung on church bells sounding different notes, with the bells being rung in a different order each time according to some definite system. The greater the number of bells the more complicated and the longer the system of changes. A bob-major involves eight bells on which 40,320 changes can be rung.

“Blood and thunder” refers here to the bloodshed and the noise of artillery that accompany battle. Nowadays it is used to describe fiction (usually poorly written) that deals primarily with action. Sometimes, when the fiction is particularly poorly written, the phrase can be spoonerized with perfect aptness into “thud and blunder.”
Bellona was the Roman goddess of war, sometimes considered to be the wife of Mars.

The Hydra was a monster killed by Hercules. It was pictured as a creature of marsh or fen with eight or nine heads (perhaps a fearful outgrowth of the octopus). When one head was cut off, two new ones grew in its place at once. Hercules had to sear the stump with fire every time he cut off a head in order to prevent new growth. The last head, which was immortal, he buried, still snapping, under a huge rock.
See note 756.

George Washington (1732–1799), as every American knows, was commander in chief of the American armies during the American Revolution. Byron admired him as an exponent of liberty and, no doubt, also because he fought against a conservative British government and won. In praising Washington, Byron was deliberately shocking the conservative elements of the British government of his day — which he enjoyed doing. (We mustn’t forget that many British in Byron’s time viewed Washington as many Americans of our day viewed Ho Chi Minh, and for the same reasons.)

The giant Enceladus (who was not, strictly speaking, a Titan) was one of those who, in the Greek myths, rebelled against Zeus and his fellow gods. The giants were defeated, of course, and buried beneath mountains as punishment. Enceladus was buried beneath the volcanic Mount Etna on Sicily (see note 251). The rumblings and fire-spittings associated with Etna made it easy to think of a restless giant pinned underneath and desperately heaving to be free.

“Allah! Hu!” was a Turkish war cry, intended to have (and often having) the same bloodcurdling, morale-shattering effect on the enemy, as did the “rebel yell” of the Confederates during the American Civil War.

In his |||italics|||Thanksgiving Ode,|||/italics||| published in 1816, Wordsworth piously asserts that when men are “array’d for mutual slaughter” they are but working out God’s will and concludes his apostrophe to God in the final line of this verse, “Yea, Carnage is thy daughter!” Byron pillories this line sarcastically, and why not, since this philosophy could be used to excuse and even sanctify every type of villainy in the world?

There was, of course, plenty of carnage in the Holy Land, both before and after the time of Jesus. The example nearest his time was the bloodshed in the Jewish rebellion from 67 to 70, ending with the horrible siege of Jerusalem.

“Ashes to ashes” is a phrase from the ritual of burying the dead, as given in the Book of Common Prayer (see note 633). The complete sentence is “Earth to earth, ashes to ashes, dust to dust; in sure and certain hope of the Resurrection unto eternal life.”

Vesuvius, located seven miles east-southeast of Naples, was considered an ordinary mountain in ancient times since there was no sign at all of volcanic activity. Then, in A.D. 79, there was a tremendous volcanic eruption that buried Pompeii and Herculaneum. After that is subsided to semiquiescence till another major eruption took place in 1631. Since then it has remained quite active, with particular liveliness in 1822, when this canto was being written.
See note 47.

Byron insisted this was true. A classmate of his names Grose, amiable, clever, witty, and a great hand at drinking songs, was killed at Waterloo, and his name was misspelled in the |||italics|||Gazette|||/italics||| as the more common “Grove.”

Frederick (1712–1786), the son of Frederick William I of Prussia, was an effeminate and homosexual prince, whom his disgusted father nearly had executed as one who would ruin the land when he succeeded to the throne. Surprisingly enough (and there probably wasn’t anyone in Europe who wasn’t surprised), he turned out to be one of the great military leaders of all time. As Frederick II, he was the greatest king Prussia was ever to have. He came to be known as Frederick the Great and was the last of Europe’s legitimate sovereigns to deserve that epithet.
He came to the throne in 1740 and almost at once seized the province of Silesia from Austria, on whose throne was Maria Theresa. It seemed that under the uncertain rule of a woman, Austria should sink into chaos and be unable to respond. As it happened, Maria Theresa turned out to be a great monarch in her own right, but the Austrian generals were no match for Frederick.
In his first major battle, that at Mollwitz on April 10–11, 1741, however, Frederick was humiliated. His army (superbly trained under his father) won, but Frederick himself panicked at a local advance of the Austrians, and fled. The next morning, far from the scene of battle, he was chagrined to receive the news that his army, without him, had won the battle. He learned the lesson from that that “one should never despair too soon,” and he observed that lesson in many dark days ahead.

In 1782 Charles Vallancey advanced the theory that the Irish language (Erse or Gaelic) was closely related to the Punic language, that of the ancient Carthaginians. In 1795 Sir Laurence Parsons agreed and suggested that the Irish were descended from the Carthaginians. This is actually quite wrong. The Punic language was a Semitic tongue closely akin to Hebrew while the Celtic language of the Irish is Indo-European. There is no closer relationship between Irish and Carthaginian than between Swedish and Arabic.

Hannibal (247–183 B.C.) was the greatest Carthaginian of them all. He fought and nearly destroyed Rome virtually singlehanded, inflicting upon the Romans the great defeat of the battle of Cannae in 216 B.C.

Carthage was founded in 814 B.C. (according to tradition) by a band of colonists from the Phoenician city of Tyre on the eastern coast of the Mediterranean. Leading the band was Dido, sister of the Tyrian king.

That “hell is paved with good intentions” was an old English proverb quoted by Samuel Johnson in the eighteenth century and something like it (“Hell is full of good intentions”) was said by St. Bernard of Clairvaux in the twelfth.
Pall Mall (once pronounced “pell mell”) is a fashionable street in London’s West End. It is the center of club life.

This incident took place in Caesar’s last battle, at Munda, Spain, in 45 B.C. The enemy army fought so well that Caesar’s forces were forced into retreat. In desperation, Caesar seized a shield and sword and rushed into battle, shouting to his retreating men, “Are you going to let your general be delivered up to the enemy?” Stung into action, his men turned and lunged forward once more, winning the day.

In the eleventh book of the |||italics|||Iliad|||/italics|||, a number of the Greek leaders are wounded and the tide begins to turn in favor of the Trojans. Even Ajax (see note 466) must retreat unwillingly, though he stands as long as possible against the swarming Trojans and is compared to “a stubborn ass in a cornfield, who is too much for the boys” who are trying to drive him out.

|||italics|||Ignis fatuus|||/italics||| is a Latin phrase meaning “foolish fire.” It is the will-o’-the-wisp (see note 741), and “foolish” refers to the travelers who follow the faint flame into the marshes.

Roger Bacon (see note 221) was one of the earliest scholars to recommend experimentation as a means for systematically exploring nature. In a letter written in 1247 he mentioned something that sounds very much like gunpowder and so he is often given the credit for discovering it. Actually, the discoverer is unknown and the knowledge of gunpowder may have been carried from China (where it was long known) to Europe by the Mongols who had plunged deep into Europe in 1240 (see note 201).
The glacis is the artificial slope that forces those who attack a fortress to charge uphill, to their own discomfort.

The phrase “cut and come again” referred originally to a large joint of meat, from which one could cut and, after having eaten, come again for another cut. By analogy, it came to mean a strategic withdrawal followed by a second advance into the fray, with the added implication of a saber cut at each advance.

This is a reference to the most famous of all psalms, the one which begins with “The Lord is my shepherd” and continues with “Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil” (Psalms 23:1, 4).
Chasseurs (the French word for “hunters”) are lightly armed men, either infantry or cavalry, whose function is to pursue the retreating enemy.

The quotation is from |||italics|||Henry IV, Part One|||/italics||| where Owen Glendower, the Welsh leader, claims he can call spirits out of the sea. To which Hotspur, the English soldier, replies dryly:
|||comment-quote|||Why so can I, or so can any man,
But will they come when you do call for them?|||/comment-quote|||
|||comment-quote-attr|||III, I, 53–54|||/comment-quote-attr|||

Hamlet, in his famous soliloquy which begins “To be or not to be,” says that many would commit suicide were it not for
|||comment-quote|||…the dread of something after death,
The undiscover’d country, from whose bourn
No traveller returns.|||/comment-quote|||
|||comment-quote-attr|||III, I, 78–79|||/comment-quote-attr|||
See note 181.
The talus is the downward slope on the defenders’ side of the rampart.

Baron Menno van Coehoorn (1641–1704) was a Dutch military engineer, the rival of Vauban (see note 707) in the theory and practice of fortification. Either name could be used as a general term for any expert in the field.

Gibraltar, the fortified peninsula near the southern tip of Spain, which covers the strategic Strait of Gibraltar, has been proverbially renowned for the strength and effectiveness of its fortification ever since the British took it from Spain in 1704 during the War of the Spanish Succession. During the American Revolution, Gibraltar was besieged by a combined Franco-Spanish force from 1779 to 1783. It held out successfully and is still British today.
For John Bull, see note 721.

When allied forces win a great battle, it is quite common for there to be some disagreement as to which of the allies performed the greater service and which would have been beaten without the other. (Very often, |||italics|||either|||/italics||| would have been beaten without the other, but this never seems to strike either ally as a suitable compromise.) At Waterloo, the British under Wellington bore the brunt of the fighting, but were hard-pressed indeed by the desperate Napoleon. The British might have been defeated but for the nick-of-time arrival of the Prussian allies late in the battle. Naturally, the Prussians felt they deserved credit for the victory.

Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher (1742–1819), a Prussian field marshal, gained his greatest fame when he was in his seventies. Prussia had been crushed by Napoleon in 1806 and nearly obliterated. In 1813, after Napoleon’s catastrophic retreat from Russia, Prussia dared face the French Emperor again. Blücher led the Prussian forces and entered Paris at their head after Napoleon’s abdication in 1814. When Napoleon returned from Elba, Blücher came out of retirement once again and it was he who, after a preliminary defeat at Napoleon’s hands, led the Prussians to a juncture with Wellington’s troops at the crucial moment in the battle of Waterloo.
Baron Friedrich Wilhelm von Bülow (1755–1816) was a Prussian general who fought in the campaign of 1813 and 1814 and served with Blücher at the battle of Waterloo.

Count August Neithardt von Gneisenau (1760–1831), a Prussian field marshal, helped reorganize the Prussian military after its virtual destruction in 1806 and then fought along with Blücher and Bülow in the war against Napoleon from 1813 to 1815.

Byron does not hesitate to take the Prussian side in the argument and point out that but for them, Wellington (whom the poet disliked intensely) would have been defeated, and his reputation destroyed.

The phrase “a little bird told me” (a variant of which Byron uses here) to indicate common rumor, or perhaps secret information, is usually considered to stem from a passage in the Bible: “Curse not the king, no not in thy thought; and curse not the rich in thy bedchamber: for a bird of the air shall carry the voice, and that which hath wings shall tell the matter” (Ecclesiastes 10:20).
Job (see note 197) is usually taken as the very epitome of patience under seemingly intolerable misfortune.

When David prepared for single battle with the Philistine giant Goliath, he “took his staff in his hand, and chose him five smooth stones out of the brook...” (I Samuel 17:40). It was with one of those stones that he killed Goliath.

In ancient times there was a period, from about 500 to 250 B.C., when the Greeks were the most sought-after fighters in the world. Armies of non-Greek nations often employed Greek mercenaries as their cutting edge. Naturally, when two such armies met, each with Greeks, there was a particularly hard-fought battle. Nathaniel Lee (1653–1692), an English dramatist, wrote a play, |||italics|||The Rival Queens,|||/italics||| in 1677 which was set in the time of Alexander the Great, and which contained the line “When Greeks joined Greeks, the was the tug of war.”

This is Hamlet’s exclamation in Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Hamlet|||/italics|||, when he considers the world and says,
|||comment-quote|||How weary, stale, flat, and unprofitable
Seem to me all the uses of this world!
Fie on’t...|||/comment-quote|||
|||comment-quote-attr|||I, ii, 133–35|||/comment-quote-attr|||
For Elysium, or the Elysian Plain, see note 367.
See note 696.

|||italics|||Bisogno|||/italics||| is an old Italian word for an indigent soldier, and an English distortion of that is “bezonian,” used to mean “rogue.” Pistol, a swaggerer, who is forever using highfalutin words he does not understand and who is a prize bezonian himself, says at one point in Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Henry IV, Part Two,|||/italics||| “Under which king, Bezonian?” (V, iii, 115). He does |||italics|||not|||/italics||| say “base Bezonian.”
However, in Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Henry VI, Part Two|||/italics|||, the Earl of Suffolk, shortly before his assassination, says contemptuously, “Great men oft die by vile bezonians” (IV, i, 134) — still not “base.” Clearly, Byron’s memory had faltered.
Livonia is the name given to that Baltic region that now makes up most of the Soviet republics of Estonia and Latvia. At the time of the siege of Izmail, Livonia had been Russian for seventy years.
William Cowper (1731–1800), an English poet, wrote |||italics|||The Task|||/italics||| in 1783, and its most famous line is the one Byron quotes here.

Rome was taken by Alaric the Visigoth in 410, after it had stood inviolate to external enemies for eight centuries. It was taken numerous times afterward and, despite its prestige as the seat of the Papacy, remained only a shadow of what it had once been into Byron’s time.

Babylon (see note 559) had its greatest fall in 539 B.C. when it was taken by Cyrus the Persian. The last notable fall in its history was in 312 B.C. when it was taken by Seleucus (see note 566), one of the generals of Alexander the Great. After that it declined rapidly and, as a living city, vanished completely.

Tyre, on the eastern shore of the Mediterranean, was taken by Alexander the Great after a dreadful nine-month siege in 332 B.C. While it continued to exist (there is a village on the site even today), its role as a mighty merchant city capable of making independent war was over.

Carthage was taken and destroyed by the Romans ini 146 B.C. A new city by that name was founded in 44 B.C. on the same site but that was taken by the Arabs in A.D. 698 and declined to nothingness thereafter.
Nineveh, capital of Assyria, was taken by Chaldeans and Medes in 612 B.C., and was utterly destroyed.

Lucius Cornelius Sulla, or Sylla in the Greek spelling (138–78 B.C.), was a Roman general who was surnamed late in life “Felix” meaning “happy” or “lucky,” for all he did seemed to turn out well. He won all his battles both against foreign foes and domestic rivals and by 82 B.C. had made himself absolute dictator of Rome. As dictator, he sanctioned a bloodbath of his enemies (hence “man-slayer,” but all went well for him and he abdicated his power in 79 B.C. when that was still at its height and spent his final year in quiet retirement. Then, when he died, his funeral pyre, after having been lit, threatened to expire under a sudden rain (a bad omen), but a strong wind sprang up as suddenly and kept it going so that his luck continued even after death.

Daniel Boone (1734–1820) was an American pioneer, who lived always in the empty wilderness he found so congenial — at a time when empty wilderness still existed. Boone lived to be eighty-six, not ninety, at Byron says in the next stanza — but eighty-six is pretty good, too. He had died only two years before these lines were written.*
|||comment-footnote|||* I am never very impressed by the praise of the simple life as sung by sophisticates city-dwelling aristocrats. They rarely show any great desire to take up that simple life, but content themselves with loving it from afar.|||/comment-footnote|||

The “Man of Ross” was John Kyrle (1637–1724), an English philantropist who received his nickname because he had estates at Ross in Hertfordshire. His character and his charities were such that Alexander Pope eulogized him in his |||italics|||Moral Essays.|||/italics||| Notice that he lived to be eighty-seven — would that virtue were always such a preservative!
Catherine II (see note 669) was sixty-one years old at the time of the siege of Izmail and was still taking lovers.

Mikhail Ilarionovich Kutuzov (1745–1813) — “Koutousow” is a mixture of the French spelling and a German ending — was a soldier from the age of twelve. He was a major general at the time of the siege of Izmail and fought with distinction there. When Napoleon invaded Russia in 1812, twenty-two years after the siege, Kutuzov was recalled from retirement and at the age of sixty-seven took over the command of the Russian forces. He led them in retreat, fought the bloody battle of Borodino, retreated again, abandoning Moscow. He waited till Napoleon was forced to abandon Moscow in his turn and then harried the Emperor all the way back to the Russian border, destroying his army.
See note 709.

A “forlorn hope” is a distortion of the Dutch |||italics|||verloren hoop|||/italics||| meaning “a lost troop,” the name given to soldiers (usually volunteers) engaged in suicide mission. It has come to mean, from the sound alone, the kind of hope that has only the faintest chance of coming to pass.

It is a kind of grim joke at the expense of fierce soldiers that, not content with killing their enemies, they eat them, too. In Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Much Ado About Nothing|||/italics||| the merry Beatrice turns this into mockery. In asking after Benedick, she says, “I pray, how many hath he killed and eaten in these wars? But how many hath he killed? for indeed, I promised to eat all of his killing” (I, i, 40–43).
A seraskier is the commanding general of Turkish troops.

This is a harking back to early beliefs in spontaneous generation — the engendering of vermin from inanimate matter. The specific mention of the “Nile’s sun-sodden slime” refers to a scene in Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Anthony and Cleopatra|||/italics||| in which a half-drunken Lepidus says to Antony, “Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun: so is your crocodile” (II, vii, 26–28).

Because Achilles was noted for being vulnerable only in the heel (see note 437), the tough sinew that attaches the muscle of the calf to the heel, is called the “Achilles’ tendon.” Byron may be bitter here, for it was the tendon “named after thee, Achilles” that, in its malformation, gave him his clubfoot.

The Pharisees were a religious party among the Jews in Roman times whom Jesus denounced: “Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites!” (Luke 11, 44). “Pharisaic” has therefore come to mean “hypocritical.”

Well-bred people supposedly find it difficult to endure harsh language and a satirist might suppose that they can stand any evil as long as that evil is not spoken of plainly. Thus Pope in his |||italics|||Moral Essays|||/italics||| has a line which speaks of one “who never mentions Hell to ears polite.” It may therefore be taken that “Hell” was the |||italics|||least|||/italics||| of what Don Juan said on this occasion.

Castelnau’s description of the siege of Izmail (see note 706) was taken largely from the personal reminiscences of Armand Emmanuel du Plessis, Duc de Richelieu (1766–1822). Du Plessis left France a little while after the outbreak of the Revolution and served in the Russian forces at Izmail when he was only twenty-four years old. Don Juan’s adventures at Izmail are modeled after Du Plessis’, as Byron admits in his Introduction to this group of cantos. Specifically, it was Du Plessis who rescued the little girl under the circumstances described here.
In 1791, the year after the siege, Du Plessis succeeded to his dukedom. In 1803 he became governor of Odessa and later governed much of the Ukraine with skill and efficiency. After Napoleon’s fall, he served twice as Prime Minister of France. He died at just about the time this canto was being written.
St. George’s collar, the insignia of the Order of St. George, was a Russian military decoration (abolished in 1917).
Castelnau again.
Hector, Achilles, and Hercules, respectively.

“Swedish Charles” is Charles XII of Sweden (1682–1718), variously called the “Alexander of the North” and “Madman of the North,” with the latter name somewhat more just. He became king at fifteen and, like Alexander, mowed down his numerically superior enemies with amazing ease. Unlike Alexander, he fought one battle too many, meeting his disaster at the battle of Poltava (deep in the Ukraine) where he was defeated by Peter the Great in 1709. He fled to Bender, in what was then Turkish territory, 110 miles north of Izmail. He persuaded the Turkish Sultan to declare war on Russia but was held as prisoner himself because he stubbornly insisted on considering himself a conquering king rather than a defeated refugee and obstinately refused to treat the Turks with the proper tact.
“Nazarene” was a word used by the Moslems for Christians who considered Jesus of Nazareth to be the Messiah.

“Aroynt” or “aroint” means “begone.” Its best-known use is in Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Macbeth|||/italics||| where the First Witch describes a sailor’s wife saying to her, “Aroint thee, witch!” (I, iii, 6).
The rank of a pasha (or pacha) was known by the number of horses’ tails attached to his standards. The highest rank bore three.

A cockney was originally the name given to small imperfect yolkless eggs occasionally laid by hens. Legend had them “cock’s eggs” or, in older English, “cocken ey,” which became “cockney.” This name was applied to anything that was foolish, imperfect, dwarfish, or spoiled, and the sturdy yeomen of the countryside thought it fit for the pallid city folk — eventually to certain Londoners in particular.
Muscadins were Parisians who, during the Revolutionary period, thought it elegant to ape English manners and to go about speaking gruffly and coarsely, as they imagined the English did.
The family name of the Duke of Wellington was Wellesley, and it is Wellington who is referred to here.
George IV of England was great not in deeds or character, but simply in size. A stone is equal to fourteen pounds, so “twenty stone” is 280 pounds.

A Roman legend has it that when Romulus first founded Rome in 753 B.C., the earliest Roman settlers experienced a shortage of women. Romulus therefore invited the menfolk of surrounding Sabine tribes to a celebration of games. While the men were away from home, the Romans raided their towns and carried off their women. Naturally, this “rape of the Sabine women” meant war — which was brought to an end through the intercession of the women themselves who had fallen in love with their Roman husbands (according to Roman legend, remember). Consequently, a Roman sort of Sabine wedding means forcible abduction.

“Timour” is Timur Lenk, better known as Tamerlane (1336–1405). He was the last of the great Mongol conquerors. A descendant of Genghis Khan, he conquered Central Asia and Persia, invaded Russia, India, and Turkey, winning every battle he fought and dying at the age of seventy as he was preparing a foray toward China.

“Zinghis” is Genghis Khan (1162–1227), an ancestor of Tamerlane and perhaps the greatest conqueror the world has seen. In his lifetime, starting rom nothing, he conquered almost all of Asia. His sons and grandsons built on what he had hone and for a short time ruled the largest continuous land empire the world has ever seen (approximately the equivalent, in area, of the modern nataions of the Soviet Union and China put together).

“Mene, mene, tekel, uphrasin” are the words described in the Bible as having been written on the wall by a ghostly hand during the feast of Belshazzar (see note 342). It is the original “handwriting on the wall,” for Daniel, the Jewish prophet, showed Belshazzar that it meant that Babylon was about to fall to the Persians and that very night, according to the biblical story, it did (Daniel 5:1–31).

Suvorov’s statement “Glory to God and to the Empress! Izmail’s ours” was, in the original Russian, a rhymed couplet. Similarly, according to legend, when Rome was on fire in 64, the Emperor Nero, a frustrated actor, couldn’t resist snatching up a lyre and singing passages from verses describing the burning of Troy.
The ancient Britons, before the coming of the Romans, painted themselves with woad, a blue dye, for decorative purposes.

Byron has indeed kept his promise so far, but this is the last time he calls to mind the epic structure of the poem. For the remaining cantos, plot sinks into the background and Juan appears only intermittently as the poet’s satiric thrusts deepen, intensify, and utterly take over the poem.

The Order of St. Vladimir was a Russian military decoration. St. Vladimir (956–1015) was the first Christian ruler over Russian territory for which, and for which |||italics|||alone|||/italics|||, he qualified for sainthood.

Hector’s brothers (all but one, the priest Helenus) were killed at Troy, either in the battles preceding the fall or in the sack that followed. Hector himself died in the battles; Hector’s father in the sack. His wife and mother were carried into captivity, as were his sisters. Saddest of all, his young son was killed by being thrown from the top of the city wall.
The muezzin is the official who cries out the hours of prayer to Moslems.

In 1822 Byron moved on to Genoa in order, again, to remain with the Countess and her family and there he wrote the final cantos of Don Juan at white heat. The ninth, tenth and eleventh cantos were written in September and October 1822 and were published on August 29, 1823.

The French poet Jean de Béranger (1780–1857) used the pun “Wellington” and “Villainton” in one of his verses. If the French try to say the former as though it were a French word spelled in that fashion, the word becomes very close to the second in pronunciation. The second word means, literally, “bad taste”. To English eyes, the second spelling brings inevitably to mind the word “villain” which Byron is perfectly willing to have it do.

There is the possibility here of a pun which, according to Byron, the printer’s devil (serving as a copyreader, I suppose) pointed out. Outraged humanity, fighting off any attempt to downgrade Wellington, shouts “Nay!” — but might they not be shouting “Ney!” pronounced exactly the same way in French and therefore opposing Wellington in the very (supposed) denial?
