Michel Ney (1769–1815) was the most spectacular (if not the most skillful) of Napoleon’s marshals. He was known as “the bravest of the brave” and, to be sure, he reached a pitch of unbelievable heroism in the course of the retreat from Moscow. If any fragment of Napoleon’s army was saved at all, it was because of Ney. He was the last man out of Russia, walking backward as though to face any last enemies there might be. He fought for Napoleon at Waterloo, but failed there and was executed for treason by order of the royalist French government on December 7, 1815.

Lord Kinnaird was the brother of Byron’s banker. He learned in 1818 from a certain Marinet of a plot to assassinate Wellington. He informed Wellington of this but tried to protect his source. Apparently, Kinnaird was convinced that he had obtained assurance that Marinet would not be harmed, but Marinet was arrested just the same, and Wellington spoke insultingly of Kinnaird — which, as Byron says, was rather shabby of the duke.

After the defeat of Napoleon, Europe’s legitimate monarchs, whom the French Revolution or Napoleon had dethroned, were restored. In France, Louis XVIII, brother of the executed Louis XVI, sat on the throne. In Spain, Ferdinand VII, who had been dethroned in 1808, reigned once more, having been restored in 1814 by Napoleon himself. In the Netherlands, William V had been deposed in 1795 but his son was restored to an enlarged kingdom that included Belgium. The numbering was started over and the son was William V.

The quotation is from Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Macbeth|||/italics|||. When the First Murderer reports to Macbeth that he has cut Banquo’s throat, Macbeth (who had ordered him to do just that) said entusiastically, “Thou art the best o’ the cut-throats” (III, iv, 18).

In 1807, when Portugal was threatened by Napoleon’s forces, its regent, John VI (ruling in place of an insane mother) fled to Brazil, then a colony of Portugal. With him went his second son, Pedro. Portugal was never occupied by the French, thanks to Wellington’s defense, and in 1816 John VI became king outright when his mother died. Nevertheless, he did not return to Portugal till 1821 and when he returned, he left behind his son Pedro as regent of Brazil.
Pedro was “the prince of the Brazils” referred to here. He supported the Brazilians against the reactionary policies of the Portuguese government and, as a matter of fact, just at about the time these lines were being written Brazil declared its independence and Pedro became its emperor as Pedro I.

Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus was, according to Roman legend, a sternly virtuous general-turned-farmer. In the fifth century B.C. he was called from the plow to be dictator, when the Romans were menaced by the Aequians. He assumed the task, defeated the Aequians, and returned to the plow, all within sixteen days, making no attempt to capitalize on his power or on the Romans’ gratitude — something, Byron more than hints, which was far above Wellington’s virtue.
Wellington was born in Dublin, so he was certainly Irish by birth, and his family had been living in Ireland for some two centuries at the time. They were, however, of English origin.

The Roman poet Horace (see note 87) was patronized by the rich Gaius Cilnius Maecenas (70–8 B.C.), who made his patronage concrete by giving Horace a Sabine farm (a small estate in Sabine territory), concerning which the poet then wrote charming verses. Byron points out that Wellington’s reward was vastly greater.

Epaminodas (418–362 B.C.) was the greatest of the ancient Thebans. He led the Theban army against the Spartans at Leuctra in 371 B.C. and defeater them. It was an unprecedented feat that hurled the Spartans from their military pre-eminence forever and ushered in a generation of greatness for Thebes, till she was defeated in turn by Philip of Macedon in 338 B.C. Epaminodas died, penniless, at the battle of Mantinea, just as he was defeating the Spartans a second time.

George Washington was of the landed gentry and quite rich by the standards of the time, so he did not die poor like Epaminodas. However, it is true that he did not use his power to enrich himself further, and if he became first President of the new country, it was by genuine acclamation and for a fixed term that he did not try to extend indefinitely.

William Pitt (1759–1806) may be considered Great Britain’s greatest Prime Minister (except possibly for Churchill). He became Prime Minister in 1783 at the age of twenty-four (!), and with one brief hiatus remained Prime Minister till his death twenty-three years later. He organized a firm and relentless opposition to Napoleon but died soon after the battle of Austerlitz, when Napoleon’s star was rising to its zenith. Byron opposed his policies but had to admit he had not used his power to enrich himself; hence he had been “ruining Great Britain gratis.”
An “antic” is what we would today call a circus clown, with a smile painted on his face. A skeleton can receive the name, too, since it is also always smiling.
Perhaps the most famous line in Shakespeare, from the beginning of the great soliloquy in |||italics|||Hamlet|||/italics||| (III, I, 56).

Hephaestion was a close friend of Alexander the Great, and presumably his homosexual lover (see note 465). When Hephaestion died in 324 B.C., Alexander went through the wildest extravagances of grief, in part out of real emotion presumably, but in part no doubt out of a self-conscious imitation of Achilles’ grief over Patroclus. Byron is saying that he is neither Wellington (Alexander) nor his flattering lickspittle admirer (Hephaestion). And yet, since Byron |||italics|||did|||/italics||| engage in homosexual amours, I wonder if he winced a little as he wrote the line.
A year before these lines were written, Napoleon had died on St. Helena at the age of fifty-two of cancer of the stomach.

This is a quote from Horace, who apostrophizes the strong digestive equipment of peasants, who can live on coarse and spicy food laden with garlic. It is comforting for the well-to-do to suppose that the peasants’ alimentary canal is divinely adjusted to poor food so that he need be offered no better. Presumably, however, the upper classes, if forced to work as hard and live as poorly, would find the peasants’ crusts just as palatable as the peasants do and digest them just as well.

Michel Eyquem de Montaigne (1533–1592) was an important essayist — in fact, he introduced the essay as a major literary form. Philosophically, he was a skeptic, wedded to no dogma. “Que sçais je?” means “What do I know?” — the natural question of a skeptic.

This same doubt concerning what one knows was expressed by Socrates (see note 699), and the Socratic viewpoint was presented by his pupil Plato, who founded a school called “the Academy” and was therefore the “first academician.”

Pyrrho of Elis (365–275 B.C.) was a philosopher who reduced extreme skepticism to a system. Nothing was to be accepted, not even what one perceived. He founded a school based on this, though some of the later skeptical philosophers traced their beliefs to Sacrates rather than to Pyrrho.
This is probably a reference to Isaac Newton (see note 700) and his authentically great discoveries.

The phrase “heaven is above all” is a kind of last resort of puzzled mankind. If problems are insoluble, leave them to God, to whom nothing (by definition) is insoluble. This, in Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Othello|||/italics|||, when Cassio is tempted into drinking by villainous Iago, the former quickly finds himself befuddled by alcohol and must find refuge in “Well; God’s above all...” (II, iii, 99).

This remark is a quote from Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Hamlet|||/italics|||. Hamlet, having escaped from his planned death in England, is now a changed man. He is through trying his hand at active plotting and has serene confidence in the guidance of heaven. He says, “There is special providence in the fall of a sparrow” (V, ii, 220–221). God takes care, in other words, of the most insignificant matters. This is, in turn, from the Bible: “Are not two sparrows sold for a farthing? and one of them shall not fall on the ground without your Father” (Matthew 10:29).
The study of the origin of the gods.
The study of the origin of the universe.

Lykanthropy, or lycanthropy (literally, “wolfmanism”) is the legendary ability of men to turn into wolves (the so-called “werewolves”). More prosaically, it is a form of delusion in which men believe themselves capable of turning into wolves.

Moses is a byword for meekness since, as the Bible says, “Now the man Moses was very meek, above all the men, which were upon the face of the earth” (Numbers 12:3). To those who believe Moses wrote every word of the first five books of the Bible, including this line, there is a problem in explaining how so meek a man could so praise his own meekness.

Melanchthon (a Greek word meaning “black earth”) was the pseudonym of Philipp Schwarzert (1497–1560), whose last name is German for “black earth.” Melanchthon was an early associate of Martin Luther and his own moderation and tact softened the teachings of the fiery and uncompromising Luther.

The “immortal Perer” is Peter the Great (see note 669) who founded St. Petersburg, the Russian capital. He labored to bring western culture to Russia and with his own hand, for instance, cut off beards of those of his noblemen (“boyars” to the Russians, and “boors” to the English, both in sound and, they thought, in fact) who hesitated to sacrifice their revered symbols of manhood on the altar of western smooth-chins.

Voltaire (see note 543), while a foe of tyranny, both political and religious, did have a soft heart for certain absolute and even tyrannical monarchs provided (1) that they seemed to respect freedom in theory, (2) that they patronized the arts, and (3) (the most important point, alas for human vanity) that they admired Voltaire. Included among these benevolent despots were Frederick II and Catherine II. It is the praise of the latter to which Byron refers.
Byron was not talking through his hat here. Less than a year after he wrote these words he left Genoa to go to Greece and lay his life on the line for liberty.

Byron was an aristocrat, remember, and a self-conscious one; even a snob. He was against tyranny and fought it with complete sincerity and with utter bravery. Still, he wanted an ideal society bestowed from above by an enlightened and benevolent ruling class. Insofar as revolutions might persuade the ruling class to benevolence, they were good. However, to have revolutions place the lower classes in a position to dictate was another thing. Byron found all forms of government unsatisfactory but said (May 1, 1821), “As for democracy, it is the worst of the whole; for what is (in fact) democracy? — an Aristocracy of Blackguards.”

Ephesus was an ancient Greek city on the Aegean shore of Asia Minor. It was at the peak of its prosperity in the time of the Roman empire, and St. Paul spent considerable time there. It petered out in the Middle Ages and, for the last four centuries, only its ruins have existed. Byron visited these ruins in 1810 and was impressed by the yelping of numerous jackals there.

“Spanish fly” is the popular name given to a species of beetle that produces an irritating substance capable of raising blisters on the skin. Taken internally, the substance is excreted by way of the kidneys and in the process the genito-urinary system is irritated. This is taken by many to be an aphrodisiac effect, so that the mere mention of it by Byron is ribald. However, the remark also revers to the irritating effect on the reactionary governments of Europe of a revolutionary movement in Spain.
In January 1820 Spanish troops mutinied and forced the reactionary King Ferdinand VII to grant a constitution. Byron’s glee was premature, however. In October 1822, just one month after this canto was written the powers of Europe met at Verona and France was granted permission to deal with the Spanish situation. In January 1823 the French army marched into Spain and by August 31, two days after this canto was published, the last of the revolution was snuffed out by French arms.

The “Attic Bee” was the name applied to Sophocles (495–405 B.C.), the Athenian dramatist (Attica was the peninsula on which Athens was located). He was so called from the sweetness of his compositions. Here Byron uses the Attic Bee as a symbol of the way in which Greek unrest was stinging the reactionary Establishment of Europe. Here at least Byron’s optimism was more justified, for the Greek cause won out (see note 383).
The Russian name for a crude cart.

During the Napoleonic Wars, when Great Britain had to finance the Continental nations opposing Napoleon and when imports of grain were less certain, agricultural prices went up and the British farmers flourished. When Napoleon was defeated, agricultural prices went down precipitously and the farmers were in distress.

Tahmasp Kuli Khan (1688—1747) was a Persian general of Turkish origin. In the early eighteenth century Persia was under three-way pressure from Turkey in the west, Afghanistan in the east, and Russia in the north. Kuli Khan held off all three, kept Persia alive, and in 1737 deposed Shah Abbas III and seized the throne, assuming the title Nadir Shah.

The line of Persian Shahs that ended with Abbas III were the Safavids, named for the founder of the house, Safi-al-din (1252–1334). This became “Sophy” in English, and the Persian monarch was referred to as “the Sophy.” Of course, Abbas III was the last of the Safavids and the usurper Nadir Shah was no Sophy, strictly speaking, though he is given the title by Byron.
For a few years, Persia under Nadir Shah seemed a conquering power again. Nadir Shah invaded India (“Hindostan”) in 1739, sacked Delhi, and carried off something like half a billion dollars in booty.

India had been conquered in 1526 by Babar (1483–1530), a descendant of Tamerlane (see note 840) and therefore of Mongol descent. He founded the Mogul empire (the variation of “Mongol”) in India, the last bit of rule in the hands of the descendants of Genghis Khan (see note 841). India remained under Mogul rule thereafter, with its last strong ruler, Aurangzeb (1618–1707), who might be called the “last of the Mongols.” After Aurangzeb, India began to fall apart; the French and English began to dominate portions of its coast. Even so, a Mogul continued to rule in Delhi for a generation after Byron’s death. It was Mohammed Shah, a great-grandson of Aurangzeb who was on the throne when Nadir Shah sacked his capital.

Nadir Shah, a Turk by origin, tried to impose the Turkish form of Islam on Persia and in 1747 was assassinated by a conspiracy of those whose religious feelings were offended. Byron maintained that Nadir Shah’s bigotry was the result of short-temperedness exacerbated by indigestion and extreme constipation. (“Costive,” four lines above, means “constipated”.)

In Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Hamlet,|||/italics||| Hamlet refers to the manner in which the lower classes pick up upper-class mannerisms, saying “the toe of the peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier, he galls his kibe” (V, I, 142–144), where a “kibe” is chapped skin on the back of the heel.
A French phrase, meaning, literally, “speaking of the boots...” It is an idiomatic device for changing the subject.

Baron Georges Cuvier (1769–1832), a French anatomist, was the outstanding biologist of Byron’s day. He studied fossils and demonstrated their relationship to living species, thus founding the science of paleontology in an important book on the subject which he published in 1812.
A religious man, Cuvier could not accept the long, slow development of life, since that would contradict the words of the Bible. He therefore maintained that the world was colonized by life many times and that each time, some great catastrophe ended life which then had to be created anew. It was the last creation with which the Bible dealt, and the ancient, early fossils were relics of former worlds.

Mammoths are extinct elephants, adapted to life in the Arctic, and covered by shaggy fur in fashion similar to the musk ox. Some varieties were larger than modern elephants and the word “mammoth,” of obscure Russian origin, has come to mean “huge.” The animal is better known to us than most extinct monsters, partly because it lived during the Ice Age and primitive men left us paintings of it. Then, too, numbers were preserved in the Siberian ice and some have been found with the flesh remaining in such good preservation that dogs could eat it. Thus, in Byron’s time, mammoths were a good example of a species of animal belonging to the former world and no longer alive.

In 1784 a fossil was discovered that seemed at first to have been the remains of some sort of sea creature. In 1801, however, Cuvier examined it and was satisfied that it had been a flying creature with wings held rigid by an immensely overgrown set of finger bones. He called it “pterodactyl” (“wingfinger”). The most startling aspect of the situation was that from the bones, it was clearly a reptile, so that Byron (rather inaccurately) can speak of a “winged crocodile.”
In Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Hamlet,|||/italics||| Hamlet complains that the world is completely out of order, saying, “The time is out of joint” (I, v, 188).
Cairngorm (or Cairn Gorme) is a yellow or smoky-brown variety of quartz crystal, so called because it is found chiefly on the mountain known as Cairngorm in central Scotland.
See note 345.
See note 638.

The seraphim are a variety of angel, mentioned in the Bible: “Above it [the Lord’s throne] stood the seraphims: each one had six wings; with twain he covered his face, and with twain he covered his feet, and with twain he did fly” (Isaiah 6:2). In later medieval, mystical theology, angels were divided into numerous classes, with the seraphim the highest.

Alexander Lanskoi was one of Catherine’s lovers, and he had the discretion to die before she tired of him. Her mourning, therefore, was great, and he seemed to be the grand passion of her life. She raised a monument to his memory and it was months before she could bring herself to take a new lover. However, he died in 1784, six years before the siege of Izmail so she had not really “just buried” him.
Yermoloff and Alexander Momonoff (or Ermolov and Mamonov) were favorites who succeeded Lanskoi in Catherine’s rugged affections.
Another swipe at Castlereagh’s oratory (see note 34).

The Sphinx in Greek mythology was a monster with the body of a lion, the wings of an eagle, and the head of a woman. The most famous Sphinx infested the region of Thebes, setting all passers-by a riddle and eating all those who could not solve it. The riddle was “What goes on four feet in the morning, on two feet at noon and on three feet in the evening; and is weaker, the more feet it goes on?” Oedipus solved the riddle by pointing out that man crawled on all fours in the morning of life, went erect in his proud noon, and used a cane for help in the old-age evening of life, and was strongest when he went erect, weakest when a baby. On hearing this, the Sphinx killed herself, while Oedipus went on to become King of Thebes and to incur great sin and suffer great tragedy. Although the riddle does not seem a very difficult one by hindsight, the Sphinx has become the personification of puzzling mystery.

A |||italics|||cavalier servente|||/italics||| is an Italian phrase meaning “a gentleman in attendance.” It was a euphemism employed for the lover of a married woman, but one who is discreet and keeps up appearances so that the husband is not humiliated. Byron was the acknowledged |||italics|||cavalier servente|||/italics||| of Countess Teresa Guiccioli while he was writing |||italics|||Don Juan|||/italics|||. She was shocked by its irreverence and urged him to give it up. Fortunately for us, he didn’t (or couldn’t).
See note 649.

The smooth-faced look of the carefully shaved French gallants is combined with a reference to youthful Paris (see note 471), prince of Troy (or Ilion), who carried off Helen of Sparta, thus starting the Trojan War — to which the last line of the stanza refers.
See note 120.

Catherine II had not inherited the throne of Russia. She was the wife of Peter, who was the nephew of the reigning Empress Elizabeth and the grandson of Peter I (the Great). When Elizabeth died, on January 5, 1762, Peter became Czar as Peter III and Catherine became Czarina. Peter, however, was childish and half-mad, treated his wife abominably, and would clearly ruin Russia if allowed to reign.
On July 9, after only half a year on the throne, he was forced to abdicate by a conspiracy of nobles, led by Gregory Orlov (1734–1783), who was then Catherine’s lover. Undoubtedly, Catherine was party to the plot and was retained as empress. Eight days after the abdication, Peter was dead. No one seems to know the details but it is inevitable that Catherine was suspected of complicity to murder her husband, although she vigorously denied it.

“‘Teterrima causa’ of all ‘belli’” is derived from a phrase from one of Horace’s satires, referring to the “worst cause of all wars,” which he held to be woman, saying this was true even before the case of Helen and the Trojan War.
See note 843.

The quotation is from a comedy entitled |||italics|||A New Way to Pay Old Debts,|||/italics||| written in 1632 by Philip Massinger (1583–1640). The protagonist in the play is Sir Giles Overreach, a cheat and extortionist, who at one point refers to someone thus: “His fortune swells him. ’Tis rank, he’s married.” This is a reference to one who goes up in the world through marriage, and Don Juan would be placed in that kind of marriage (at least temporarily) if he became Catherine’s lover.
The quotation comes from Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Hamlet,|||/italics||| where Hamlet is describing his dead father to his remarried mother (III, iv, 59–60).

The Simplon is one of the passes over the Alps, that mountain barrier that seems impassable but that was crossed both by Hannibal and by Napoleon. In 1800 Napoleon ordered a road built over the pass which was completed in 1806 — before this canto was written. (The date of completion of the Simplon Tunnel was 1905. It is 12¼ miles long and the longest in the world. In 1816 Byron crossed over the Simplon Pass in traveling from Switzerland into Italy. No doubt he would have appreciated having been able to use the tunnel.)
Laudanum is an alcoholic tincture of opium; “black drop” is an acid extract of opium.

The word “prove” is used here in its older meaning of “test.” Alexander Pope, in his |||italics|||Eloisa to Abelard|||/italics||| has Eloisa say, “Not Caesar’s empress would I deign to prove.” That is, she wouldn’t stoop to test the position of empress without love, but would marry |||italics|||only|||/italics||| for love.
See note 561.
Thetis was the sea nymph who was mother of Achilles, but in poetry her name is often used to symbolize the ocean generally.
See note 581.
Pallas was one of the epithets of the Greek goddess Athena (patroness of Athens), who was often described as gray-eyed.

Valeria Messalina was the third wife of the Roman Emperor Claudius. She was executed in A.D. 48 on the grounds of immorality and treason when she was still only in her early twenties. The later scandalmongers had a field day exaggerating her adulteries into incredible nymphomania. As a result, her name has become a byword for immorality.
Byron seems to forget that Catherine, far from being in the “prime of life,” is now sixty-one and that he himself commented on this in the previous canto (see note 817).
The phrase is from the drinking song of Iago in Shakespeare’s |||italics|||Othello|||/italics||| (II, iii, 69).
Land granted in Russia included the peasants on it.

Clytemnestra was the wife of Agamemnon, leader of the Greek forces at the siege of Troy (see note 85). Clytemnestra had taken a lover while Agamemnon was absent and when her lord returned, she had him murdered. This is a glance at the fact that Catherine had had her husband, Peter, murdered (see note 910). Byron might also be imlying that he would rather have died than have stayed married to Lady Byron.

Elizabeth I of England (1533–1603) was widely considered a virgin, was even known as “the Virgin Queen,” and may well have been one, in a technical manner of speaking. However, she did take lovers, of whom the last was the Earl of Essex (thirty-three years younger than she) and hence was only “half-chaste.” However, Elizabeth was a tightfisted woman with money (which seemed a vice to courtiers, but was a blessing to the people and could well account for much of her popularity) and she did non shower wealth on her lovers directly as Catherine did.

Robert Devereux, second Earl of Essex (1566–1601) was Queen Elizabeth I’s last favorite. Essex was an incompetent soldier and politician, however, and in the end was foolish enough to think he could organize a coup against the aged queen. The coup was quickly crushed, and Elizabeth, a queen before she was a woman, had Essex executed. Grief may have shortened her life thereafter, but she was already sixty-eight and in failing health, so how much longer would she have lived anyway?

Miss Protasoff’s function was a tribute to Catherine’s highly original approach to the matter of love. When Catherine took a lover, she based her initial decision entirely on his looks, but there remained the vital point that in actual practice he might belie his looks. Therefore it was the duty of a trusted woman attendant of meticulous taste in such things to try the prospective lover in bed. If she said he would do, then Catherine would take him on. |||italics|||“L’|||/italics||||||italics|||É|||/italics||||||italics|||p|||/italics||||||italics|||rouveuse”|||/italics||| might be translated as “the testeress.”
See note 914.

This is a reference to the Scottish lawyer Henry Peter Brougham (last name pronounced “Broom”) (1778–1868), a great reformer and moralist. Byron hated him when he discovered it was Brougham, not Jeffrey, who had written that lacerating criticism of his first book. See note 215.
